FRESHMAN BANQUET
Pandemonium raged for
more than 25 minutes last
night as tumblers, plates and
shattered windows filled the
air of the Annapolis Armory
when a band of nearly fifteen
sophomores tried to break up
the freshman banquet. Almost all the municipal resources of the small state capital were exhausted after the
police department, the fire department and finally the local
National Guard were called
out to quell the riot. Finally,
order was restored and the
freshmen continued their banquet peacefully and extremely
happily.

AVOCATIONS
President Goodnow's recent declaration concerning.the future
of extra-curricula activities was a rather distinct surprise to the
majority of those who consider themselves leaders in activities.
The belief has been rife that with the gradual adoption of the New
Plan would come the slow suffocation of all athletic and nonathletic activities, the statements of Dean Ames and others notwithstanding.
It has been generally accepted that a man cannot at the same
time be a good student and an interested participant in other campus work. Many people at Johns Hopkins (official and unofficial)
consider axiomatic the assertion that a student must entertain a
sort of fanatical enthusiasm for his studies to be rated a "good"
student.
Such people would naturally deprecate activities unqualifiedly
without attempting to discover wherein the undesirability lies. And
there is a danger, it is true.
The danger, as has been said many times in the past, lies in
overdoing them. It is unfortunate that, as soon as a man finds
himself successful in one activity, he believes it his duty to himself or his fraternity to try out two or three more. His success
in the first endeavor gives him a reputation on which he rides to•
greater heights in the succeeding attempts.
The results are obvious. Activities become the man's vocation instead of his avocation. He becomes a "campus leader." He
studies whenever he may find time. He achieves Success, and incidentally forfeits part of his education.
Another result of the existing scheme of activities is that the
real "kick" derived from participation is tasted by a small minority.
Most students think that the only ones who genuinely enjoy their
work on activities are those at the head, those about whom a certain glamor attaches itself. Consequently, these others take no interest. Moreover, if a student knows that he has not sufficient time
to devote to three or four activities, he will not attempt any at all.
President Goodnow does not entertain the belief that under
the New Plan it will be possible for a man to devote time to more
than one or two activities. He does, probably, hope that activities
will exist as avocations, for he will not allow them to be raisons
d'etre of students' college careers.

the banquet season. Everyone, from the Hopkins reporters on the
dailies to the members of the Greek department, catches the banquet Spirit in much the same way as young and old throw themselves into the spirit of Christmas. The banquet excitement, coming at the very time when spring fever is most likely to creep into
, the veins of man, should, in reality be indicative of the expenditure

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
A survey of the number of students working their way through
school at Ohio State University was
recently instituted and an extremely
interesting and, indeed, amazing result was disclosed. According to
the replies to the questionnaire,
ninety per cent of the male students
enrolled, are working their way
through the university in whole or
in part. Three men out of every
five work during the school year to
help support themselves. Even discounting the natural exaggeration of
the true circumstances, which usually occurs in these instances, the result is indeed flattering to the character of the students.

Much unfavorable comment has
recently been aroused among the
student body at the University of
North 'Carolina, as a result of the
suspension by the Student Council
of thirteen of their fellows for gambling. Information leading to this
drastic action was suppoYedly received from a disgruntled party.
The President of the Student Council has, because of the severe opposition to his decree, granted an apPeal to several of the offenders, who
maintain that the real issue involves
Qn interpretation of the honor system.

George Washington University
has organized a Graduate Endowment Committee whose purpose it is
to have each senior voluntarily sign
a pledge at the time of his graduation, which will be payable every
Year. They believe that eventually
this would become a tradition which
each senior would fulfill as a matter
of pride.

PREMATURE SPRING FEVER PENETRATES
HAUNTS OP BOOK-WORMS AND UNDERGRADS
Flowers that bloom in the springtra-la may have something to do
with the case.
A balminess in the air, that gets
into the blood and stirs up agreeable fancies, may be the cause; or
a general feeling of elation due to
warmth of sunshine and fragrance
of soft breezes; or maybe an afterglow of emotion from moon madness of the night before.
Whatever the reason, it is certain
that the undergraduate library in
Gilman Hall has taken on a most
disquieting personality. The very
atmosphere of the place has become
restrictive, prison-like.
Those who enter its doors and
bravely attempt to buckle down to
some task find difficulty in fixing
attention on the work in hand.

Those who come to talk become
more valuable and noisy and less
easily put down by warning glances
from the librarian.
.In through the window come all
the myriad noises of spring—indefinable sounds of things coming to
life.
All around is the melodious chirping and trilling of scores of feathered migrants lately come up from
the South.
One's mind keeps wandering away
from history, or literature or languages to the botanical gardens
nearby, with their wealth of plantlife, and to the frog-ponds lying in
quiet beauty a little deeper in the
woods.

color in their escutcheon, but being
doubtless influenced by the generally
accepted derogatory connotation of
the term have abandoned it. Blue
and white is the most popular combination, being used by over sixty

happily.

AVOCATIONS
President Goodnow's recent declaration concerning.the future
of extra-curricula activities was a rather distinct surprise to the
majority of those who consider themselves leaders in activities.
The belief has been rife that with the gradual adoption of the New
Plan would come the slow suffocation of all athletic and nonathletic activities, the statements of Dean Ames and others notwithstanding.
It has been generally accepted that a man cannot at the same
time be a good student and an interested participant in other campus work. Many people at Johns Hopkins (official and unofficial)
consider axiomatic the assertion that a student must entertain a
sort of fanatical enthusiasm for his studies to be rated a "good"
student.
Such people would naturally deprecate activities unqualifiedly
without attempting to discover wherein the undesirability lies. And
there is a danger, it is true.
The danger, as has been said many times in the past, lies in
overdoing them. It is unfortunate that, as soon as a man finds
himself successful in one activity, he believes it his duty to himself or his fraternity to try out two or three more. His success
in the first endeavor gives him a reputation on which he rides to•
greater heights in the succeeding attempts.
The results are obvious. Activities become the man's vocation instead of his avocation. He becomes a "campus leader." He
studies whenever he may find time. He achieves Success, and incidentally forfeits part of his education.
Another result of the existing scheme of activities is that the
real "kick" derived from participation is tasted by a small minority.
Most students think that the only ones who genuinely enjoy their
work on activities are those at the head, those about whom a certain glamor attaches itself. Consequently, these others take no interest. Moreover, if a student knows that he has not sufficient time
to devote to three or four activities, he will not attempt any at all.
President Goodnow does not entertain the belief that under
the New Plan it will be possible for a man to devote time to more
than one or two activities. He does, probably, hope that activities
will exist as avocations, for he will not allow them to be raisons
d'etre of students' college careers.

the banquet season. Everyone, from the Hopkins reporters on the
dailies to the members of the Greek department, catches the banquet Spirit in much the same way as young and old throw themselves into the spirit of Christmas. The banquet excitement, coming at the very time when spring fever is most likely to creep into

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
A survey of the number of students working their way through
school at Ohio State University was
recently instituted and an extremely
interesting and, indeed, amazing result was disclosed. According to
the replies to the questionnaire,
ninety per cent of the male students
enrolled, are working their way
through the university in whole or
in part. Three men out of every
five work during the school year to
help support themselves. Even discounting the natural exaggeration of
the true circumstances, which usually occurs in these instances, the result is indeed flattering to the character of the students.

Much unfavorable comment has
recently been aroused among the
student body at the University of
North 'Carolina, as a result of the
suspension by the Student Council
of thirteen of their fellows for gambling. Information leading to this
drastic action was suppoYedly received from a disgruntled party.
The President of the Student Council has, because of the severe opposition to his decree, granted an apPeal to several of the offenders, who
maintain that the real issue involves
Qn interpretation of the honor system.

George Washington University
has organized a Graduate Endowment Committee whose purpose it is
to have each senior voluntarily sign
a pledge at the time of his graduation, which will be payable every
Year. They believe that eventually
this would become a tradition which
each senior would fulfill as a matter
of pride.
